definition: noisy/cacophonous/to make noise/to disturb/to vent (feelings)/to fall ill/to have an attack (of sickness)/to go in (for some activity)/to joke
theatrical work (play, opera, TV series etc)/dramatic (change, increase etc)/acute/severe

sentences.english: Is there a subtle good-cop, bad-cop routine playing out?
sentences.chinese: 這是一場微妙的紅白臉鬧劇嗎？

sentences.english: Good message to China. No more Arunachal visa drama now.
sentences.chinese: 給中國傳達了很好的信息，別再搞阿邦簽證鬧劇了。

sentences.english: It seemed to be a farce and it made us doubled up with laugher.
sentences.chinese: 它看起來很像鬧劇，我們都笑彎了腰。

sentences.english: So the successful slapstick comedy Kino started up.
sentences.chinese: 於是，成功的鬧劇《影院》就此開始了。

sentences.english: The audience roared at the farce.
The Italian proverb is a sadly apt footnote to the latest round of European shenanigans.
sentences.chinese: 對於最新這輪歐洲鬧劇來說，這是個極爲恰當的註腳。

sentences.english: If I recall, such good-natured horseplay happens in American elections, too.
sentences.chinese: 我記得這種非惡意的鬧劇在美國選舉史上也曾經發生。

sentences.english: I wonder if it was intended to be a farce.
sentences.chinese: 我懷疑他們想把它演成一部鬧劇。

sentences.english: A poorly planned or executed mold set-up can resemble a comedy of errors.
sentences.chinese: 模具安排的糟糕計劃或行動就像一個錯誤的鬧劇。

sentences.english: The project itself has been widely viewed as a total farce.
sentences.chinese: 這個計劃本身廣泛的被視作一場大鬧劇。

sentences.english: The Swiss Spaghetti Harvest hoax generated an enormous response.
sentences.chinese: 這個意大利通心粉收穫節的鬧劇引發了巨大的反響。

sentences.english: You know, I think this whole damn thing is a farce.
sentences.chinese: 你知道麼，在我看來，這簡直就是一場鬧劇。

sentences.english: One of these skits, "The King of Beasts" resembles a traditional frontier prank.
sentences.chinese: 一出滑稽短劇《獸王》酷似傳統的邊疆鬧劇。

sentences.english: An adhesive piece of candy wrap caused a ridiculous farce.
sentences.chinese: 一張糖紙引出一場荒唐的鬧劇。

sentences.english: I found it was totally a farce.
sentences.chinese: 我發現這完全是場鬧劇。

sentences.english: What you'd often do is go to see farces or comedies.

definition: to bombard/to bomb/(fig.) to criticize/to roast
to expel (a member of an organization)/to fire (an employee)
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
to resist/to make a stand and fight (against)
sacrificial victim/sb who is expendable/item sold at a loss
